reviewText: I really enjoyed this movie. I love the old ones. Sex is a thing you can imagine. Great acting. Real dialog, not just yelling and meaingless violence. A keeper.

reviewText: I wish this set would also contain "Reckless Moment" (1949, Joan Bennett and James Mason), "The Accused" (Loretta Young) and "My Name is Julia Ross" (Nina Foch, 1945), but I'm happy to finally get  good copies from "Woman in Hiding" and "Female on the Beach".I'm not familiar with the two other film noirs, but I'm sure they will be equally good.When this TCM set was published in 2012, I was waiting for the price to go down, but it never did. Finally I checked the TCM website a while ago, it didn't even offer this DVD set anymore. I wonder why?
summary: Two of the best chick film noirs
Title: N/A

reviewText: I will start off by saying that I am a Joan Crawford Fan. I have seen and purchased many of her movies. I have enjoyed each and every one of them for different reasons and as I did I began to appreciate the woman for her talents. I purchased this collection because of a review stating that the Joan Crawford Vehicle within this collection "Female on the Beach" was a GREAT movie. I got excited and purchased the collection(since you can not buy it as a single DVD). Unfortunately, in my opinion, "Female of the Beach" was not the better of the films in this collection and certainly not a reason to buy the collection like I had done. The reason to buy this collection is for the stories themselves. The great filming in black and white and the Noir/Thriller feeling behind them. I personally loved "Woman in Hiding" staring Ida Lupino. It was an edgy film where you get pulled into the story. The Ester Williams story was also a GREAT film. A sort of who done it. You find yourself wondering is it him or is it him and then you find out and its like WOW! now that was a great movie. The Joan Crawford story "Female on the Beach" was a good story but nothing to write home about. If you enjoy her other films then yes this one is worth watching but not for the reason to purchase this collection. Buy it for "Woman in Danger" and look at the other 3 films as bonuses. That is my opinion.
summary: A Great Collection of Film Noir Classics
Title: N/A

reviewText: TCM and Universal did a pretty good job on releasing this collection of four film noir/thriller films. As noted by another reviewer about "The Unguarded Moment" the quality is not as good as expected, but it's not horrible. as for the other three, their great! Each movie has their own disk with lots of bonus features.The features included vary, but majority are the same, which are: Ben Mankiewicz introduction (only on "Woman in Hiding" disk), publicity stills, scene stills, behind-the-scenes photos, movie posters, original movie poster art, lobby card, wardrobe and makeup stills, lobby cards and TCMDb article.The movie included are:"Woman in Hiding" (1950/Full frame/b&w;/93mins)Ida Lupino, Stephen McNally, Howard Duff, Peggy Dow, John Litel, Don Beddoe; Directed by Michael Gordon"Female on the Beach" (1955/Full frame/b&w;/97mins)Joan Crawford, Jeff Chandler, Jan Sterling, Cecil Kellaway, Judith Evelyn, Charles Drake; Directed by Joseph Pevney"The Unguarded Moment" (1956/Letterbox/color/95mins)Esther Williams, George Nader, John Saxon, Edward Andrews, Les Tremayne, Edward Platt; Directed by Harry Keller"The Price of Fear" (1956/Widescreen/b&w;/80mins)Merle Oberon, Lex Barker, Charles Drake, Gia Scala, Warren Stevens; Directed by Abner BibermanOverall this is a great collection of film noirs/thrillers and I would recommend this.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have been a Joan Crawford fan for years and have been waiting patiently for her 1955 film "Female on the Beach" to make its way to home video and now it's here! This movie NEVER saw a commercial release on VHS or DVD until now as all copies of the film on auction sites were terrible copies made from television. Now the movie comes in glorious DVD quality format and the transfer is one of the best I have ever seen for a movie that is over 50 years old! Plus, if you play the disc in a Blu Ray player the movie looks even more flawless. It does come in this set along with three other movies I have yet to see, but by far "Female" is the reason I bought this.In "Female on the Beach" Joan plays a lonely widow named Lynn Markham who comes to her dead husband's beach house to decide whether or not to sell it. Lynn is lonely as heck, that is until she meets hunky Jeff Chandler (a stud Joan was having an affair with off-screen). He pursues her, she refuses, but finally gives in to him and marries the guy. Soon, she believes he is a killer who only married her for her money.The script is far from Oscar-winning, but Crawford looks beautiful with her jewels and costumes and Jeff Chandler is any woman or gay guy's dream boat. Joan later commented, "I liked "Female on the Beach". Jeff Chandler was an excellent actor, but the only thing wrong with it is the same thing that hurts so many melodramas: a lack of crediblity".The film comes in full-screen format and no one seems to know if the picture was originally shot in widescreen or not. Still, it is so nice to have this rare gem on DVD. Sit back, pour a cup of hot tea and watch Joan own this picture like no one else. A wonderful way to spend a rainy day for 90 mintes!
Title: N/A
